ground_truth: Edgar drops the truck into gear and follows him, slowly, trolling along behind him. Zed's office is a circular, windowed room elevated above the main floor of MIB headquarters. Jay and Kay sit across the desk from Zed. There are five video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk, and on each monitor is another Man in Black, in different parts of the world, the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image. While Zed talks, he goes through paperwork on his desk. Next to him, his computer screen beeps importantly. Zed looks over at it. Jay and Kay come out the front of MIB headquarters. Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner, steps out of a cab in the meat-packing district, still carrying the ornate box and his beloved cat. A moment later, the Orkin van pulls to a stop across the street. He heads into Leshko's, a Russian diner. Rosenberg comes into the tiny restaurant, squinting in the relative darkness. At a table in the middle, he sees a man eating alone—an enormous, dignified, yet profoundly strange-looking man in his mid-fifties. Rosenberg walks carefully over to the table, but does not sit down. He steps forward, to face Rosenberg, who sets the ornate box on the table. Rosenberg and the Arquillian stare at each other for a long moment—and then embrace each other. The embrace has an odd, formal quality to it, like mafiosi coming to a sitdown. They hold on, long and hard, and both seem choked with emotion. Finally, they break apart and take their seats. They speak in a bizarre alien tongue, which is subtitled. The driver hands over some documents. The guy digs out two other cards and hands those over. Mrs. Redgick is in front, moaning in pain, holding her swollen belly. Kay straightens up, fast. Mrs. Redgick screams again. Redgick gets out of the car, worried. Suddenly a tentacle whips out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, cracks the whip once, and wraps around the door post, grabbing hold. Now a second tentacle whips out, but this one wraps around Jay's neck and pulls tight. Jay looks down at the creature cooing and nestling on his chest. It vomits on him. Back in the car, Jay wipes the last of the puke off his suit while Kay starts up the car. Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. Kay is furiously searching through the tabs; Jay is standing behind him, a little embarrassed. Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand and gives the guy a buck. He smacks the paper down on the hood in front of Jay, the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Edgar lowers the lorry into motion and trails him, gradually, trawling along behind him. Zed's workplace is a round, glazed chamber elevated above the central level of MIB headquarters. Jay and Kay sit opposite the bureau from Zed. There are five video displays on a partition behind Zed's bureau, and on each screen is another Man in Black, in various regions of the globe, the metropolis identifier and a chronometer ticking in a corner of the picture. While Zed converses, he goes through documentation on his bureau. Next to him, his computer display beeps importantly. Zed glances over at it. Jay and Kay emerge out the front of MIB headquarters. Rosenberg, the jewelry shop proprietor, steps out of a taxi in the meat-packing zone, still carrying the elaborate container and his cherished feline. A moment later, the Orkin van halts to a pause across the avenue. He proceeds into Leshko's, a Russian eatery. Rosenberg enters the diminutive eatery, squinting in the relative dimness. At a table in the center, he perceives a man dining alone—an immense, dignified, yet profoundly peculiar-looking man in his mid-fifties. Rosenberg walks cautiously over to the table, but does not take a seat. He moves forward, to face Rosenberg, who places the elaborate container on the table. Rosenberg and the Arquillian gaze at each other for a lengthy moment—and then clasp each other. The embrace has an odd, formal quality to it, like mafiosi arriving at a sitdown. They hold on, long and tight, and both appear choked with sentiment. Finally, they separate and take their places. They converse in a strange extraterrestrial language, which is subtitled. The chauffeur hands over some papers. The guy extracts two other cards and hands those over. Mrs. Redgick is in front, moaning in agony, holding her swollen abdomen. Kay straightens up, quickly. Mrs. Redgick cries out again. Redgick gets out of the vehicle, concerned. Suddenly a tentacle lashes out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, snaps once, and coils around the door jamb, clutching hold. Now a second tentacle lashes out, but this one coils around Jay's throat and pulls tight. Jay glances down at the being cooing and nestling on his torso. It regurgitates on him. Back in the vehicle, Jay wipes the last of the vomit off his attire while Kay starts up the automobile. Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. Kay is furiously inspecting through the tabs; Jay is standing behind him, somewhat embarrassed. Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand and gives the guy a dollar. He slaps the paper down on the bonnet in front of Jay, the sheets turned open to a headline in script so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The truck is dropped into gear by Edgar and he is followed slowly, trolled along by Edgar. A circular, windowed room is the location of Zed's office, elevated above the main floor of MIB headquarters. Across the desk from Zed sit Jay and Kay. On a wall behind Zed's desk are five video monitors, and on each monitor, another Man in Black is seen in different parts of the world, with the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image. While paperwork is gone through by Zed on his desk, he talks. Next to him, an important beep is made by his computer screen. The screen is looked over at by Zed. Out of the front of MIB headquarters come Jay and Kay. A cab is stepped out of by Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner, in the meat-packing district, still carrying the ornate box and his beloved cat. A moment later, the Orkin van is pulled to a stop across the street. Leshko's, a Russian diner, is entered by him. Into the tiny restaurant comes Rosenberg, squinting in the relative darkness. At a table in the middle, a man eating alone is seen by him—an enormous, dignified, yet profoundly strange-looking man in his mid-fifties. Carefully, Rosenberg walks over to the table, but a seat is not taken by him. Forward, he steps to face Rosenberg, who sets the ornate box on the table. Rosenberg and the Arquillian stare at each other for a long moment—and then each other is embraced by them. To it, the embrace has an odd, formal quality, like mafiosi coming to a sitdown. Long and hard, they hold on, and with emotion, both seem choked. Finally, they break apart and take their seats. In a bizarre alien tongue, they speak, which is subtitled. Some documents are handed over by the driver. Two other cards are dug out by the guy and handed over. In front, in pain, Mrs. Redgick is moaning, holding her swollen belly. Fast, Kay straightens up. Again, a scream is made by Mrs. Redgick. Out of the car steps Redgick, worried. Suddenly, from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, a tentacle whips out, the whip is cracked once, and the door post is wrapped around, grabbed hold of. Now a second tentacle whips out, around Jay's neck it wraps, and it pulls tight. Down at the creature, Jay looks, cooing and nestling on his chest. On him, it is vomited. Back in the car, the last of the puke is wiped off Jay’s suit while the car is started up by Kay. Close on various supermarket tabloids as they are flipped through by a hand. Through the tabs, Kay is searching furiously; behind him, Jay is standing, a little embarrassed. From the stand, a copy of the Weekly World News is pulled by Kay and a buck is given to the guy. The paper is smacked down on the hood in front of Jay, the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Edgar shifts the truck into gear and follows slowly behind. Zed's office is a circular, elevated room with windows above MIB's main floor. Jay and Kay sit across from Zed at his desk, which is backed by five video monitors showing different Men in Black worldwide, each with a city name and time displayed. While speaking, Zed sorts through paperwork, occasionally glancing at his beeping computer screen. Jay and Kay exit MIB headquarters as Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner, steps out of a cab in the meat-packing district, carrying an ornate box and his beloved cat. Across the street, an Orkin van arrives. Entering Leshko's Russian diner, Rosenberg, adjusting to the dim light, approaches a table where a strange yet dignified man in his fifties sits alone. Rosenberg places the ornate box on the table, and after a formal, emotional embrace, they converse in a subtitled alien language. Mrs. Redgick, in pain and holding her belly, screams, prompting Kay to straighten quickly. Redgick exits the car, worried, as a tentacle emerges, wrapping around the door post. Another tentacle wraps around Jay's neck. The creature coos on Jay's chest, then vomits. Jay wipes the vomit off as Kay starts the car. At a newsstand, Kay searches tabloids with Jay embarrassed behind him. Kay buys a Weekly World News and slaps it on the hood, opened to a headline as prominent as one for the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Edgar shifts the truck into gear and follows slowly. Zed's office, a circular room with windows, sits above the main floor of MIB headquarters. Jay and Kay are across from Zed, who has five monitors behind him, each showing a Man in Black worldwide, with city names and clocks. Zed speaks while sorting paperwork, his computer beeping importantly. Jay and Kay leave MIB headquarters as Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner, exits a cab in the meat-packing district, carrying an ornate box and cat. The Orkin van stops across the street. Rosenberg enters Leshko's, a Russian diner, seeing a solitary, odd-looking man. He approaches the table, places the box down, and they embrace formally like mafiosi. They sit and converse in a strange alien language with subtitles. Mrs. Redgick is in front, moaning in pain, holding her swollen belly. Kay reacts quickly as Mrs. Redgick screams. Redgick leaves the car, worried. A tentacle emerges, wraps around a door post, then another seizes Jay's neck. Jay sees a creature on his chest, which vomits on him. Back in the car, Jay cleans his suit while Kay drives. Kay flips through supermarket tabloids, finds the Weekly World News, pays, and shows Jay a large headline.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Edgar, maintaining a steady focus, smoothly drops the truck into gear. With deliberate care, he slowly follows behind, taking his time as he trails the man. Zed's office is a distinct, circular room with multiple windows. It sits elevated above the main floor of MIB headquarters, offering a panoramic view. Inside the room, Jay and Kay find themselves seated directly across from Zed’s desk. Behind Zed, five video monitors are mounted on a wall, each displaying a different Man in Black located in various parts of the world. Each monitor screen includes the name of the city and a clock ticking away in one corner. As Zed speaks, he multitasks, flipping through the paperwork scattered across his desk. Beside him, his computer screen beeps with an air of importance, capturing Zed’s attention momentarily.

Meanwhile, Jay and Kay exit through the front of MIB headquarters. Elsewhere, Rosenberg, who owns a jewelry store, steps out of a cab arriving in the meat-packing district. He is still carrying the ornate box as well as his beloved cat. Just a moment later, the Orkin van pulls up to a halt directly across the street. Rosenberg then makes his way into Leshko's, a well-known Russian diner. As Rosenberg enters the small, dimly lit restaurant, he squints, adjusting to the relative darkness inside. In the center of the room, seated at a table, is a man dining alone. This man, who is enormous and dignified, yet profoundly strange-looking, appears to be in his mid-fifties. Rosenberg approaches the table with caution, yet he does not sit down. Instead, he steps forward to face Rosenberg, who carefully places the ornate box on the table. The two, Rosenberg and the Arquillian, lock eyes, sharing a long moment of silence, and then they embrace warmly. The embrace has a peculiar, formal quality, reminiscent of mafiosi convening for a serious meeting. They cling to each other tightly, each appearing choked with emotion, before finally parting and taking their seats. The conversation that follows is conducted in a bizarre alien tongue, with subtitles providing the translation.

Elsewhere, the driver efficiently hands over some important documents. The man then retrieves and hands over two additional cards. At the same time, Mrs. Redgick, visibly in distress and moaning in pain, sits in front, holding her very swollen belly. Quickly, Kay straightens up, sensing urgency. Mrs. Redgick lets out another piercing scream. Mr. Redgick exits the car, clearly worried. Suddenly, a tentacle lashes out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, cracking like a whip, and wraps around the car's door post for support. Then, a second tentacle emerges, this time wrapping tightly around Jay's neck. In a surprising twist, Jay glances down at the creature that is now cooing and settling comfortably on his chest. To Jay's dismay, it proceeds to vomit on him. Afterwards, back inside the car, Jay diligently wipes the remaining puke from his suit while Kay proceeds to start up the car. Meanwhile, various supermarket tabloids are closely zoomed in on as a hand flips through them. Kay, with urgency, searches through the array of tabloids; standing behind him is Jay, who appears somewhat embarrassed. Kay retrieves a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand and hands over a dollar to the attendant. He then dramatically smacks the paper onto the hood in front of Jay, with the pages open to a headline in a typeface so large it seems fitting for announcing the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Edgar, maintaining a steady and unwavering focus, smoothly places the truck into gear, with a precise and practiced motion. With deliberate and cautious care, he slowly follows behind, taking his time as he carefully trails the man ahead. Zed's office is a distinct and uniquely circular room adorned with multiple wide and expansive windows. It sits elevated above the main floor of MIB headquarters, offering an impressive panoramic view. Inside this room, Jay and Kay find themselves seated directly across from Zed’s orderly desk. Behind Zed, five video monitors are prominently mounted on the wall, each one displaying a different Man in Black positioned in various parts of the world. Each monitor screen includes, for each location, the name of the city, alongside a clock ticking away in one corner. As Zed speaks, he multitasks seamlessly, flipping through the paperwork scattered across his desk. Beside him, his computer screen beeps with an air of importance, momentarily capturing Zed’s attention.

Meanwhile, Jay and Kay step out through the front of the imposing MIB headquarters. Elsewhere, Rosenberg, the owner of a jewelry store, steps out of a cab that has just arrived in the bustling meat-packing district. He is still carrying his ornate box as well as his beloved and cherished cat. Just a moment later, the Orkin van pulls up to a halt directly across the street from him. Rosenberg then makes his way into Leshko's, a well-known and popular Russian diner. As Rosenberg enters this small, dimly lit restaurant, he squints, adjusting to the relative darkness that envelops him inside. In the center of the room, seated at a table, is a solitary man dining alone. This man, who is enormous and dignified yet profoundly strange-looking, appears to be in his mid-fifties. Rosenberg approaches the table with caution and respect, yet he does not choose to sit down. Instead, he steps forward to face Rosenberg, who carefully places the ornate box on the table. The two, Rosenberg and the Arquillian, lock eyes, sharing a long, meaningful moment of silence, and then they embrace warmly. The embrace carries a peculiar, formal quality, reminiscent of mafiosi convening for a serious and weighty meeting. They cling to each other tightly, each appearing choked with emotion, before finally parting and taking their seats. The conversation that follows is conducted in a bizarre alien tongue, with subtitles thoughtfully providing the translation.

Elsewhere, the efficient driver hands over some important and necessary documents. The man then retrieves and hands over two additional, smaller cards. At the same time, Mrs. Redgick, visibly in distress and moaning in pain, sits in the front, clutching her very swollen belly. Quickly, Kay straightens up, sensing an urgency in the situation. Mrs. Redgick lets out another piercing scream. Mr. Redgick exits the car, clearly worried and concerned. Suddenly, a tentacle lashes out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, cracking like a whip, and wraps around the car's door post for needed support. Then, a second tentacle emerges, wrapping tightly around Jay's neck. In a surprising twist, Jay glances down at the small creature that is now cooing and settling comfortably on his chest. To Jay's dismay, it proceeds to vomit unceremoniously on him. Afterwards, back inside the car, Jay diligently wipes the remaining puke from his suit while Kay proceeds to start up the car. Meanwhile, various supermarket tabloids are zoomed in on as a hand flips through them quickly. Kay, with urgency, searches through the array of tabloids; standing behind him is Jay, who appears somewhat embarrassed and sheepish. Kay retrieves a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand, handing over a crisp dollar to the attendant. He then dramatically smacks the paper onto the hood in front of Jay, with the pages open to a headline in a typeface so large it seems almost fitting for announcing the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Edgar deftly shifts the truck into gear and proceeds to trail the other vehicle at a leisurely pace, ensuring to maintain a consistent, albeit slow, speed to keep him in sight as they move along. Inside MIB headquarters, the scene shifts to Zed's office, a unique circular space elevated above the main floor, its windows offering a broad view. Jay and Kay are seated across from Zed at his desk. Behind Zed, five video monitors are mounted on the wall, each displaying a different Man in Black stationed in various global locations, with the city name and a clock ticking away in the corner of each screen. As Zed engages in conversation, he multitasks by shuffling through the paperwork laid out on his desk. His attention is momentarily diverted when his computer screen emits an important beep, prompting him to glance over. Transitioning to a new scene, Jay and Kay emerge from the entrance of MIB headquarters. Meanwhile, in the meat-packing district, Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner, alights from a cab, carefully holding both an ornate box and his cherished cat. Moments later, an Orkin van arrives and comes to a halt across the street. Rosenberg makes his way into Leshko's, a Russian diner, where he enters the dimly lit establishment, his eyes adjusting to the subdued lighting. In the center of the room, he spots a solitary man dining—a man of considerable size, dignity, and notably peculiar appearance, seemingly in his mid-fifties. Rosenberg approaches the table cautiously yet refrains from sitting down immediately. The other man rises to face Rosenberg, who places the ornate box on the table. There is a lingering moment where Rosenberg and the Arquillian exchange an intense gaze before they embrace each other. The embrace is formal, almost ritualistic, reminiscent of a mafioso sitdown, characterized by a long and emotionally charged grip. Both finally release and take their seats, beginning a conversation in an alien tongue, which is helpfully subtitled for clarity. Meanwhile, a driver hands over several documents, and another individual produces and hands over two additional cards. Out in front, Mrs. Redgick is doubled over in pain, clutching her swollen belly. Reacting swiftly, Kay straightens his posture, as Mrs. Redgick emits another anguished scream. Alarmed, Redgick exits the car in a flurry of concern. Suddenly, a tentacle emerges with startling speed from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, snapping like a whip before coiling around the doorpost to secure itself. Soon after, a second tentacle lashes out, this time encircling Jay's neck with a tight grip. Jay looks down to find a peculiar creature affectionately nestled against his chest, which promptly vomits on him. Back inside the vehicle, Jay endeavors to clean the remnants of the vomit from his suit as Kay turns the ignition, preparing to drive off. The scene cuts to a close-up of various supermarket tabloids being flipped through by an eager hand. Kay is intensely searching through the publications, with Jay standing slightly behind, wearing an expression of mild embarrassment. Kay eventually singles out a copy of the Weekly World News, offers a dollar to the vendor, and then emphatically slaps the newspaper on the hood of the car in front of Jay, the pages conspicuously open to a headline so prominently displayed it would seem appropriate for a proclamation as significant as the Second Coming.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Edgar follows him by driving the truck slowly behind. At MIB headquarters, Zed's office is a circular, elevated, windowed room. Inside, Jay and Kay sit across from Zed, who speaks as he shifts through paperwork, occasionally glancing at his beeping computer screen. Behind Zed, five monitors display different Men in Black around the world, alongside city names and clocks. Meanwhile, Rosenberg exits a cab in the meat-packing district, carrying his ornate box and cat, and enters Leshko's, a Russian diner. Inside the dim restaurant, he approaches a table where a peculiar, dignified man in his mid-fifties sits alone. They share a formal embrace reminiscent of a mafioso meeting, laden with emotion, before conversing in a subtitled alien language. Elsewhere, Mrs. Redgick is in pain, holding her swollen belly, prompting Kay and Jay to react. Suddenly, a tentacle emerges from between her legs, latching onto a door post, as another wraps around Jay’s neck, pulling it tight. Jay is left with a creature cooing on his chest, which then vomits on him. Later, Jay wipes off the mess while Kay starts the car. They visit a store, where Kay flips through supermarket tabloids. He selects the Weekly World News, pays for it, and slams it open on the hood for Jay, highlighting a headline with an enormous typeface.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description:
Edgar drops the truck into gear, the vehicle's engine humming with familiarity as he follows him, slowly, trolling along behind him. Zed's office is a circular, windowed room elevated above the main floor of MIB headquarters, an ultra-secretive organization in New York City that monitors extraterrestrial life on Earth. Jay and Kay, seasoned agents known for their work in alien affairs, sit across the desk from Zed. There are five video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk, and on each monitor is another Man in Black, in different parts of the world like Tokyo and Paris, the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image, reflecting the global operations of their agency. While Zed talks, he goes through paperwork on his desk, which includes top-secret files on interstellar diplomacy. Next to him, his computer screen beeps importantly, alerting him to a potential threat detected via satellite. Zed looks over at it. Jay and Kay come out the front of MIB headquarters, the iconic building disguised as a nondescript office to avoid public scrutiny. 

Rosenberg, the jewelry store owner known for his rare gem collection, steps out of a cab in the meat-packing district, historically known for its transformation into a trendy neighborhood, still carrying the ornate box and his beloved cat. A moment later, the Orkin van, often used by undercover agents as a disguise, pulls to a stop across the street. He heads into Leshko's, a Russian diner famed for its authentic borscht and cozy atmosphere. Rosenberg comes into the tiny restaurant, squinting in the relative darkness that contrasts with the bright lights of the street. At a table in the middle, he sees a man eating alone—an enormous, dignified, yet profoundly strange-looking man in his mid-fifties, an Arquillian, known for their advanced technology and peaceful demeanor. Rosenberg walks carefully over to the table, but does not sit down. He steps forward, to face Rosenberg, who sets the ornate box on the table. Rosenberg and the Arquillian stare at each other for a long moment—and then embrace each other. The embrace has an odd, formal quality to it, like mafiosi coming to a sitdown, suggesting a deep bond formed over critical alliances. They hold on, long and hard, and both seem choked with emotion, their shared history evident in their expressions. Finally, they break apart and take their seats. They speak in a bizarre alien tongue, which is subtitled for comprehension. The driver hands over some documents, essential papers for their clandestine operations. The guy digs out two other cards and hands those over, identification required for their intergalactic business.

Mrs. Redgick is in front, moaning in pain, holding her swollen belly, a clear sign of her imminent and unusual childbirth. Kay straightens up, fast, recognizing the urgency of the situation. Mrs. Redgick screams again. Redgick gets out of the car, worried, as any expectant father might feel. Suddenly a tentacle whips out from between Mrs. Redgick's legs, cracks the whip once, and wraps around the door post, grabbing hold with unexpected strength. Now a second tentacle whips out, but this one wraps around Jay's neck and pulls tight, reminding him of the unpredictable nature of alien biology. Jay looks down at the creature cooing and nestling on his chest, a newborn alien adjusting to its new environment. It vomits on him, a reflexive reaction common among its species. Back in the car, Jay wipes the last of the puke off his suit while Kay starts up the car, ready to drive off to their next assignment.

Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. Kay is furiously searching through the tabs; Jay is standing behind him, a little embarrassed by the public's fascination with outlandish stories. Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand, a publication notorious for its extraordinary and far-fetched headlines, and gives the guy a buck. He smacks the paper down on the hood in front of Jay, the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming, indicating a story of immense importance or intrigue.

In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Finally they break apart and take their seats. They speak in a bizarre alien tongue which is subtitled. The driver hands over some documents. The guy digs out two other cards and hands those over. Mrs Redgick is in front moaning in pain holding her swollen belly. Kay straightens up fast. Mrs Redgick screams again. Redgick gets out of the car worried. Suddenly a tentacle whips out from between Mrs Redgick's legs cracks the whip once and wraps around the door post grabbing hold. Now a second tentacle whips out but this one wraps around Jay's neck and pulls tight. Jay looks down at the creature cooing and nestling on his chest. It vomits on him. Back in the car Jay wipes the last of the puke off his suit while Kay starts up the car. Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. Kay is furiously searching through the tabs. Jay is standing behind him a little embarrassed. Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand and gives the guy a buck. He smacks the paper down on the hood in front of Jay. the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

Jay and Kay sit across the desk from Zed. There are five video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk and on each monitor is another Man in Black in different parts of the world the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image. While Zed talks he goes through paperwork on his desk. Next to him his computer screen beeps importantly. Zed looks over at it. Jay and Kay come out the front of MIB headquarters. Rosenberg the jewelry store owner steps out of a cab in the meatpacking district still carrying the ornate box and his beloved cat. A moment later the Orkin van pulls to a stop across the street. He heads into Leshko's a Russian diner. Rosenberg comes into the tiny restaurant squinting in the relative darkness. At a table in the middle he sees a man eating alone—an enormous dignified yet profoundly strangelooking man in his midfifties. Rosenberg walks carefully over to the table but does not sit down. He steps forward to face Rosenberg who sets the ornate box on the table. Rosenberg and the Arquillian stare at each other for a long moment—and then embrace each other. The embrace has an odd formal quality to it like mafiosi coming to a sitdown. They hold on long and hard and both seem choked with emotion. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Finally they break apart and take their seats. They speak in a bizarre alien tongue which is subtitled. The driver hands over some documents. The guy digs out two other cards and hands those over. Mrs Redgick is in front moaning in pain holding her swollen belly. Kay straightens up fast. Mrs Redgick screams again. Redgick gets out of the car worried. Suddenly a tentacle whips out from between Mrs Redgick's legs cracks the whip once and wraps around the door post grabbing hold. Now a second tentacle whips out but this one wraps around Jay's neck and pulls tight. Jay looks down at the creature cooing and nestling on his chest. It vomits on him. Back in the car Jay wipes the last of the puke off his suit while Kay starts up the car. Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. Kay is furiously searching through the tabs. Jay is standing behind him a little embarrassed. Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand and gives the guy a buck. He smacks the paper down on the hood in front of Jay. the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

Jay and Kay sit across the desk from Zed. There are five video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk and on each monitor is another Man in Black in different parts of the world the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image. While Zed talks he goes through paperwork on his desk. Next to him his computer screen beeps importantly. Zed looks over at it. Jay and Kay come out the front of MIB headquarters. Rosenberg the jewelry store owner steps out of a cab in the meatpacking district still carrying the ornate box and his beloved cat. Now a second tentacle whips out but this one wraps around Jay's neck and pulls tight. Jay looks down at the creature cooing and nestling on his chest. It vomits on him. Back in the car Jay wipes the last of the puke off his suit while Kay starts up the car. Close on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips through them. He smacks the paper down on the hood in front of Jay. the pages turned open to a headline in typeface so large one would think it reserved for the Second Coming.

Jay and Kay sit across the desk from Zed. There are five video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk and on each monitor is another Man in Black in different parts of the world the city name and a clock ticking in a corner of the image. test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Earl plunks the bicycle into the lake and chases it, quickly, washing away behind it. Ned's library is a triangular, glassed-in hut floating above the main garden of UFO museum. Max and Leo lounge below the counter from Ned. There are five lava lamps on a shelf behind Ned's counter, and on each lamp is another Creature in Pink, in different regions of the universe, the planet name and a sundial spinning in a corner of the picture. While Ned narrates, he swims through seashells on his counter. Next to him, his television screen rings importantly. Ned glances over at it. Max and Leo drift out the back of UFO museum. Goldberg, the candy shop manager, hops out of a skateboard in the flower-picking park, still juggling the simple lamp and his treasured fish. An instant later, the Pest van sails to a stop beside the square. He flies into Klesko's, a French bakery. Goldberg floats into the tiny pub, blinking in the relative brightness. At a stool in the corner, he notices a woman singing alone—an enormous, regal, yet profoundly odd-looking woman in her early-twenties. Goldberg swims cautiously over to the stool, but does not lie down. He hops backward, to face Goldberg, who places the simple lamp on the stool. Goldberg and the Brazilian gaze at each other for a fleeting second—and then chuckle with each other. The chuckle has an odd, informal tone to it, like sailors coming to a standoff. They let go, light and fast, and both appear filled with elation. Finally, they spring apart and take their beds. They gesture in a bizarre aquatic dance, which is captioned. The clerk tosses over some toys. The girl roots through three other bags and tosses those over. Miss Tredgick is in back, laughing with joy, cradling her furry hat. Leo leans down, slow. Miss Tredgick laughs again. Tredgick jumps out of the bus, delighted. Instantly, a vine crawls in from under Miss Tredgick's feet, plays the flute once, and coils around the window frame, clutching fast. Now a third vine crawls in, but this one coils around Max's ankle and pulls loose. Max glances up at the flower chirping and swaying on his head. It sneezes on him. Back in the bus, Max wipes the last of the sneeze off his bag while Leo jumps up the bus. Close on various comic strips as a foot flips under them. Leo is calmly perusing under the strips; Max is standing beside him, a little intrigued. Leo snatches a copy of the Monthly Space Journal from the shelf and offers the woman a penny. He tosses the journal up on the seat beside Max, the strips spun wide to a caption in typeface so tiny one would think it reserved for the Third Passing.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Edgar follows slowly in a truck. Zed's office is circular and elevated in MIB headquarters, where Jay and Kay sit across from him. Behind Zed are monitors showing other MIB agents worldwide. As Zed sorts through paperwork, his computer beeps. Outside, Jay and Kay leave the headquarters. Rosenberg, carrying a box and a cat, exits a cab in the meat-packing district and enters Leshko's diner. Inside, he meets a strange-looking man and places the box on the table. They share an emotional, formal embrace and converse in an alien language. Meanwhile, Mrs. Redgick screams from labor pains, and tentacles emerge, one wrapping around Jay. He holds a creature, which vomits on him. Later, Jay cleans his suit and Kay searches tabloids, eventually buying a copy of the Weekly World News, revealing a significant headline.
